content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities while ensuring border security operations are carried out effectively. In the "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009," key terms defined include "Indian tribe," "Secretary," and "Secretary concerned," specifying their meanings in relation to the Act. The Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Defense, and the Secretary of Commerce have jurisdiction over specific lands as defined in the Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009. SEC. 4. BORDER PROTECTION STRATEGY. The Secretary and other relevant officials must develop a border protection strategy for the US international land borders by September 30, 2009, in consultation with tribal, State, and local officials. The strategy should include a comparative analysis of border security levels. The border protection strategy for US international land borders must include a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through various security measures such as pedestrian fencing, vehicle barriers, additional Border Patrol agents, and natural barriers. The border protection strategy includes analyzing the efficacy of natural barriers, advanced technology like unmanned aerial vehicles, and additional Border Patrol agents in response to unauthorized border crossings. The development of tactical surveillance, multi-source information integration, and response analysis in difficult terrain and adverse environmental conditions is crucial for border security. Enhanced cooperation with intelligence, security, and law enforcement agencies in Mexico and Canada is also important for detecting, reporting, and analyzing border threats. The analysis includes the cost and impacts of security measures, such as land acquisition costs and related litigation. The assessment includes land acquisition costs, construction costs, maintenance costs over 25 years, contractor costs, management and overhead costs, and impacts on wildlife and habitats. The curr_chunk discusses the impacts on wildlife habitats, water quality, and hydrology along the border, including the costs of mitigating these adverse effects on various types of lands. The curr_chunk addresses the replacement or restoration of severed wildlife migration corridors with protected corridors of equivalent biological functionality, as determined by relevant authorities. The curr_chunk discusses the impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life on residents near the border, as well as the fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands and waters related to the US land borders. The curr_chunk focuses on lands near the US borders managed for conservation purposes, including National Parks, National Forests, Bureau of Land Management, and Fish and Wildlife Service jurisdiction. The curr_chunk lists various types of land under different jurisdictions, including the Department of Defense, Department of Commerce, tribal lands, and other relevant departments. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for strategic border security management based on comparative security, cost-benefit analysis, and protection of investments in public lands. The curr_chunk discusses required training for natural resource protection for Customs and Border Protection agents or other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure. The curr_chunk focuses on cultural resource training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in overseeing the construction or operation of border security infrastructure or patrolling tribal lands. The curr_chunk emphasizes coordinating appropriate training with relevant agencies and tribal governments to achieve border security objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. The curr_chunk highlights the adverse impact on natural and cultural resources from border security activities. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. Amendment to improve operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security must gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States, following the border protection strategy. Priority should be given to using remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other low impact border enforcement techniques. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with various entities to minimize the impact on the environment, culture, and safety near border enforcement sites. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with various entities to minimize the impact on the environment, culture, and safety near border enforcement sites. This subsection aims to enhance commerce, safety, and quality of life for communities near proposed actions, without creating or negating any legal rights or affecting eminent domain laws. The Secretary of Homeland Security is not required to install specific resources along the international border if deemed ineffective for operational control. The Secretary of Homeland Security may decide not to use certain resources along the international border if they are deemed ineffective or if the costs and impacts outweigh the benefits. The Secretary of Homeland Security is prohibited from starting any construction of border infrastructure until 90 days after submitting a border protection strategy to Congress. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, will develop a monitoring and mitigation plan to address ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan will include measures to mitigate environmental impacts. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, will develop a monitoring and mitigation plan to address ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan shall include measures to preserve wildlife migration corridors, key habitats, and ecological connectivity, address invasive species control, and prevent their spread. The mitigation plan for border security infrastructure includes adapting to climate change impacts, controlling invasive species, maintaining hydrological functionality, implementing adaptive management, and protecting cultural and historical resources. The Secretary may carry out a mitigation plan on various lands regardless of ownership or responsibility, to protect cultural and historical resources near the international border of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security may transfer funds to other Federal agencies for expenditure under programs in consultation with the owner or entity responsible for managing lands described in the mitigation plan. Transfer funds from the Department of Homeland Security to other Federal agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands. The Secretary may accept donations for developing and implementing the mitigation plan required under subsection (a) without being subject to reprogramming requirements. The Secretary can accept donations for developing and implementing the required mitigation plan, and use appropriated funds for border security infrastructure for the same purpose.
